article:
The 'modes of persuasion' are devices in rhetoric that classify the speaker's
appeal to the audience. They are: ethos, pathos, and logos.

Aristotle's [http://classics.mit.edu/Aristotle/rhetoric.1.i.html On Rhetoric]
describes the modes of persuasion thus:

:Persuasion is clearly a sort of demonstration, since we are most fully
persuaded when we consider a thing to have been demonstrated.

:Of the modes of persuasion furnished by the spoken word there are three kinds.
[...] Persuasion is achieved by the speaker's personal character when the
speech is so spoken as to make us think him credible. [...] Secondly,
persuasion may come through the hearers, when the speech stirs their emotions.
[...] Thirdly, persuasion is effected through the speech itself when we have
proved a truth or an apparent truth by means of the persuasive arguments
suitable to the case in question.
